data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Doing things haphazardly breeds distrust. If they don't present results until after raising all the new capital, it conveys the feeling that everything announced so far hasn't yielded sufficiently strong or interesting financial results for shareholders to invest their money in the company. Then it makes sense that they did it the way they did. "First we raise the money, and then we give the results, just in case they disappoint the investors, we already have the money." I don't think it's honest. But that's just my personal opinion. I was happy with the company's progress and excited about the recent good news, but not with this move. And personally, I don't care if the shares skyrocket or rise gradually; that's not what my opinion is about. I'm talking about transparency, good faith, and honesty. Simply put.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: On the other hand, the overbuying of newly issued shares also seems strange to me, because there isn't a very advantageous offer at the initial offering price for existing shareholders, given that the price was practically at market value, with only a minimal advantage. Where is the offer for shareholders? You can buy them at that price today, so why don't you go to the market to buy the ones you couldn't buy at the discounted price? I have my doubts about the effectiveness of how things have been handled, in such a rushed manner. Time will tell

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: One thing doesn't negate the other. I mean, you can't start building a house from the roof down. The new company is currently losing money. But I'm not just referring to the new acquisition; Haydale has had financial problems from the beginning, a decade ago. Now it was starting to recover, after bleeding dry for a long time. First, get your house in order, and then you do whatever else is necessary. Present results, confirm the promised cost reductions, and confirm according to management. From there, we continue moving forward. There's no need to mortgage your resources again if there's no rush, because the company hasn't yet confirmed its good performance with strong financial results, aside from some good news, but without any clear results. The first thing to do is start there, consolidating the foundations, which you don't have.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Thoughtful comments, particularly from Roberson and Albatross. From what I can see, the business has changed very significantly over the past 12 to 15 months - now focussing on commercialising its existing graphene applications, and focussing more on the UK. In so doing it has sharply reduced its cost base and, arguably, improved its chances of success in a (graphene) sector that has seen, let's be honest, much failure and little success. The company we now have doesn't seem to have the structure that could drive incremental growth in fragmented sectors (like housing), and hence the acquisition of SMCC seems sensible - to provide such a structure. The price tag still seems high, but fingers crossed it will succeed. From a shareholding perspective I think this makes Haydale a less speculative punt (though still speculative to a degree) with a greater chance of incremental (but less spectacular) success. I imagine that will please some shareholders and not others. And of course they can still develop other commercial applications that might be more spectacularly successful. Let's hope so.

The fact that its loss making isn’t too relevant as it had been aggressively growing to establish itself in the sector which in theory we can now capitalise on. Becoming profitable may still be some time off but growing revenues will bolster the share price in the medium term. Big dilution sure but if the alternative was a bit of a drift higher followed by weak sales our best case would end up being an unfavourable sale.

data.author: ROBERSON

At a time that seemed opportune to strengthen the company's value by improving the current share price and thereby appease the long-suffering shareholders by presenting positive financial results and driving up the share price, are they embarking on the risky project of asking for yet another sacrifice from the already hard-suffering shareholders? They say this move is to compensate the long-suffering shareholders. I don't agree, with all due respect to the board's decisions.

data.author: ROBERSON

data.author: ROBERSON

Errors of this magnitude are how companies end up in bankruptcy. Let's hope that doesn't happen to this company, given its promising future outlook.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: What I meant by the company's financial problem regarding analysts' opinions is that it exists, and it's real, whether it's from Yahoo Finance with AI, or from any reputable analyst, from whom the AI ​​draws its information. data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Furthermore, you believe that decisions are made by consensus with the company, but these are just beliefs and assumptions, such as the idea that the change in management could also have been agreed upon with them, or the purchase of SMCC, etc. There will surely be decisions made by consensus for the good of the company, but I don't know to what extent they are decisive in the final decision-making. We shareholders can think or believe things freely, but that doesn't necessarily mean it will happen, have happened, or be true. And this is also an opinion, my personal one. I also don't believe they're responsible for everything the company might have done wrong, because management will have the final say, regardless of Cavendish's advice, which includes things like changing the name or the management, for example. In any case, I prefer to look to the future rather than the past, hence my concern that things are done right for the future good of the company, and that as few mistakes as possible are made. But that's not in my hands, as I'm just a shareholder who can only offer my opinion

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: My analysis wasn't based on Yahoo Finance, although there might be some similarities in the final conclusions, because Yahoo Finance uses AI to obtain those results. This AI researches multiple analysts simultaneously, which may include those I've researched. Regarding Cavendish, I see you have considerable confidence in them for whatever reason, and I have no objection. However, I understand the trades you mentioned they make, as it's normal, especially when a company has such low trading volume. But I'm referring to another type of trade, already discussed in this forum, with specific dates and times. These were instances of stock purchases, without any intervening sales, and instead of the price rising or falling due to supply and demand, it not only didn't rise, it didn't even stay the same, but the stock was sold below the trading price at that moment, inexplicably.

Well, if things have improved now, even if not dramatically, but the measures they decided to take a year ago have managed to improve things, even if only slightly, it would be fair to say so, just as they bluntly stated last year that things were going badly and outlined the adjustments they had to make. That's fine, we need to be clear and realistic and know where we stand. Because it seems that shareholders went into the offer to acquire new shares with enthusiasm, but without real information, and the same mistakes of the past are being repeated, which is why many shareholders are disappointed with the company's performance, especially those who have been invested longer and made disastrous investments.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Roberson, I think they did indeed "trail" the FY results as being unspectacular when touching on them in the 12th December RNS -

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Doing things haphazardly breeds distrust. If they don't present results until after raising all the new capital, it conveys the feeling that everything announced so far hasn't yielded sufficiently strong or interesting financial results for shareholders to invest their money in the company. Then it makes sense that they did it the way they did. "First we raise the money, and then we give the results, just in case they disappoint the investors, we already have the money." I don't think it's honest. But that's just my personal opinion. I was happy with the company's progress and excited about the recent good news, but not with this move. And personally, I don't care if the shares skyrocket or rise gradually; that's not what my opinion is about. I'm talking about transparency, good faith, and honesty. Simply put.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: On the other hand, the overbuying of newly issued shares also seems strange to me, because there isn't a very advantageous offer at the initial offering price for existing shareholders, given that the price was practically at market value, with only a minimal advantage. Where is the offer for shareholders? You can buy them at that price today, so why don't you go to the market to buy the ones you couldn't buy at the discounted price? I have my doubts about the effectiveness of how things have been handled, in such a rushed manner. Time will tell

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: One thing doesn't negate the other. I mean, you can't start building a house from the roof down. The new company is currently losing money. But I'm not just referring to the new acquisition; Haydale has had financial problems from the beginning, a decade ago. Now it was starting to recover, after bleeding dry for a long time. First, get your house in order, and then you do whatever else is necessary. Present results, confirm the promised cost reductions, and confirm according to management. From there, we continue moving forward. There's no need to mortgage your resources again if there's no rush, because the company hasn't yet confirmed its good performance with strong financial results, aside from some good news, but without any clear results. The first thing to do is start there, consolidating the foundations, which you don't have.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Thoughtful comments, particularly from Roberson and Albatross. From what I can see, the business has changed very significantly over the past 12 to 15 months - now focussing on commercialising its existing graphene applications, and focussing more on the UK. In so doing it has sharply reduced its cost base and, arguably, improved its chances of success in a (graphene) sector that has seen, let's be honest, much failure and little success. The company we now have doesn't seem to have the structure that could drive incremental growth in fragmented sectors (like housing), and hence the acquisition of SMCC seems sensible - to provide such a structure. The price tag still seems high, but fingers crossed it will succeed. From a shareholding perspective I think this makes Haydale a less speculative punt (though still speculative to a degree) with a greater chance of incremental (but less spectacular) success. I imagine that will please some shareholders and not others. And of course they can still develop other commercial applications that might be more spectacularly successful. Let's hope so.

data.author: Albatross747
data.content: Think there’s a lot going on behind the curtain, it may seem like they should have hunkered down and used just heat to make some money and let the share price improve but their duty is to the long term success of the company not just to short term making the shareholders happy. Without an integrated distribution method sales of Justheat could well have been looking to underperform. In theory this acquisition will help us hit the ground running. The fact that its loss making isn’t too relevant as it had been aggressively growing to establish itself in the sector which in theory we can now capitalise on. Becoming profitable may still be some time off but growing revenues will bolster the share price in the medium term. Big dilution sure but if the alternative was a bit of a drift higher followed by weak sales our best case would end up being an unfavourable sale.

data.author: Jennimee
data.content: Agreed. It does seem a strange move to make but surely they have done their own due diligence and have a structured plan to move the business forward? The commercial platform seems to be raising heads especially now we know the share offer was over subscribed. I think the company have viable product which potentially could be a market leader will we would hope would bring a market leading share price too. Big plans looking to materialise in the coming year? I think so! Good luck all

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: The dilution of the current share price through a new capital increase of over three billion new shares to buy a loss-making company—after having to auction off and enter bankruptcy proceedings this year (2025) for its US branch, and selling off its Thai branch at a loss due to financial problems—doesn't seem very reasonable to me. At a time that seemed opportune to strengthen the company's value by improving the current share price and thereby appease the long-suffering shareholders by presenting positive financial results and driving up the share price, are they embarking on the risky project of asking for yet another sacrifice from the already hard-suffering shareholders? They say this move is to compensate the long-suffering shareholders. I don't agree, with all due respect to the board's decisions.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Crystal ball time I guess, but with a lot of shares due to hit the market at a price of 0.5p in the near future, I doubt the share price will move too much in the coming weeks - unless we have some surprising / positive news. There'll be activity in w/c 5th Jan with the the EGM on the 6th and the admission of consideration shares that week. Then there is the final results announcement scheduled for "early February". Suggest things will be clearer then.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: What I meant by the company's financial problem regarding analysts' opinions is that it exists, and it's real, whether it's from Yahoo Finance with AI, or from any reputable analyst, from whom the AI ​​draws its information. Until proven otherwise, and there's only one way to do that, which is by presenting the results without the delay that's going to happen in this case, to send positive signals that could help finance the company, whether through the market with options, a share offering, loans, or whatever they deem most appropriate and advantageous. On the other hand, I'm surprised that there has been so much oversubscription by shareholders without having real and properly updated data. It surprises me greatly. I see too much enthusiasm, which could cause them to lose sight of the real objective.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Furthermore, you believe that decisions are made by consensus with the company, but these are just beliefs and assumptions, such as the idea that the change in management could also have been agreed upon with them, or the purchase of SMCC, etc. There will surely be decisions made by consensus for the good of the company, but I don't know to what extent they are decisive in the final decision-making. We shareholders can think or believe things freely, but that doesn't necessarily mean it will happen, have happened, or be true. And this is also an opinion, my personal one. I also don't believe they're responsible for everything the company might have done wrong, because management will have the final say, regardless of Cavendish's advice, which includes things like changing the name or the management, for example. In any case, I prefer to look to the future rather than the past, hence my concern that things are done right for the future good of the company, and that as few mistakes as possible are made. But that's not in my hands, as I'm just a shareholder who can only offer my opinion

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: My analysis wasn't based on Yahoo Finance, although there might be some similarities in the final conclusions, because Yahoo Finance uses AI to obtain those results. This AI researches multiple analysts simultaneously, which may include those I've researched. Regarding Cavendish, I see you have considerable confidence in them for whatever reason, and I have no objection. However, I understand the trades you mentioned they make, as it's normal, especially when a company has such low trading volume. But I'm referring to another type of trade, already discussed in this forum, with specific dates and times. These were instances of stock purchases, without any intervening sales, and instead of the price rising or falling due to supply and demand, it not only didn't rise, it didn't even stay the same, but the stock was sold below the trading price at that moment, inexplicably.

data.author: Sometimes
data.content: I also hope that Haydale succeeds, as I am also invested. With regard to your previous post about Cavendish and the Yahoo report, yes Cavendish worked with the previous management, but they also might in their duty to all shareholders have been involved in the management changes, whilst they are paid by Haydale I think they also have fidicuary responsibility to all shareholders. The Yahoo report is AI generated and will have combined all data it can find, but will always give the "Investment" warning for all Companies that have prior losses, which is inevitable in new technology companies and is after all why AIM evolved and has its tax breaks. Regarding trading in the market, my hypothesis on how the professionals operate is, imagine you are an ambitious fund manager whose usual investment value would be a multiple of the normal market daily trade value and let us go back a few weeks to when the share price was 0.6p with a spread of 0.55-0.65 and say the size is 1.5m shares bid with one market maker and offered with 2 also 1.5m each, the wise fund manager would instruct his dealer to bid 0.56 for 10m shares with a minimum start size of 3m. If at close of play the dealer or his market maker friend has accumulated 5m shares there will be a load of smaller trades under 0.56 and then the late reporting of the 5m at 0.56 and they will all show as sales or unknown! Also the two market makers who were offering at 0.65  if they had not been involved in the trades they would try and muscle in by lowering their offer prices, to attract the buyer to them. In this scenario buying looks like selling and the price has fallen!! Just my thoughts.

data.author: ROBERSON

And I don't know if the decisions are, or can be, agreed upon with Cavendish, which I assume they are, but in the recent past, fatal mistakes have been made for the development of the business, and although I'm aware of the change in the company's direction, starting with the top executives, the advisors in this case remain the same, which doesn't inspire much confidence. In the transactions handled by the market maker, I've often seen deals that, at the very least, can be described as strange, and I'm not the only person on this forum who has had a negative opinion about this.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Haydale Graphene's overall score is primarily influenced by its financial difficulties, with persistent net losses and cash flow problems overshadowing recent positive corporate events and technical momentum. While strategic developments and partnerships offer growth potential, financial stability remains a crucial concern. This is what professional market analysts think about the company's latest news. We shareholders can talk, criticize, exchange opinions, think, or believe whatever we want, but without results until February, the market, in its objective analysis, without bias, speculation, or speculation, has already formed its opinion of Haydale. And that could be a heavy burden if the results presented in February aren't satisfactory enough for the market. This is a risk that could have been avoided by presenting results in December. I hope I'm wrong and that in February I have to eat my words; that would be a huge success for all of us who want this company to succeed.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: One thing doesn't negate the other. I mean, you can't start building a house from the roof down. The new company is currently losing money. But I'm not just referring to the new acquisition; Haydale has had financial problems from the beginning, a decade ago. Now it was starting to recover, after bleeding dry for a long time. First, get your house in order, and then you do whatever else is necessary. Present results, confirm the promised cost reductions, and confirm according to management. From there, we continue moving forward. There's no need to mortgage your resources again if there's no rush, because the company hasn't yet confirmed its good performance with strong financial results, aside from some good news, but without any clear results. The first thing to do is start there, consolidating the foundations, which you don't have.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Thoughtful comments, particularly from Roberson and Albatross. From what I can see, the business has changed very significantly over the past 12 to 15 months - now focussing on commercialising its existing graphene applications, and focussing more on the UK. In so doing it has sharply reduced its cost base and, arguably, improved its chances of success in a (graphene) sector that has seen, let's be honest, much failure and little success. The company we now have doesn't seem to have the structure that could drive incremental growth in fragmented sectors (like housing), and hence the acquisition of SMCC seems sensible - to provide such a structure. The price tag still seems high, but fingers crossed it will succeed. From a shareholding perspective I think this makes Haydale a less speculative punt (though still speculative to a degree) with a greater chance of incremental (but less spectacular) success. I imagine that will please some shareholders and not others. And of course they can still develop other commercial applications that might be more spectacularly successful. Let's hope so.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: The dilution of the current share price through a new capital increase of over three billion new shares to buy a loss-making company—after having to auction off and enter bankruptcy proceedings this year (2025) for its US branch, and selling off its Thai branch at a loss due to financial problems—doesn't seem very reasonable to me. At a time that seemed opportune to strengthen the company's value by improving the current share price and thereby appease the long-suffering shareholders by presenting positive financial results and driving up the share price, are they embarking on the risky project of asking for yet another sacrifice from the already hard-suffering shareholders? They say this move is to compensate the long-suffering shareholders. I don't agree, with all due respect to the board's decisions.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: What I meant by the company's financial problem regarding analysts' opinions is that it exists, and it's real, whether it's from Yahoo Finance with AI, or from any reputable analyst, from whom the AI ​​draws its information. Until proven otherwise, and there's only one way to do that, which is by presenting the results without the delay that's going to happen in this case, to send positive signals that could help finance the company, whether through the market with options, a share offering, loans, or whatever they deem most appropriate and advantageous. On the other hand, I'm surprised that there has been so much oversubscription by shareholders without having real and properly updated data. It surprises me greatly. I see too much enthusiasm, which could cause them to lose sight of the real objective.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Furthermore, you believe that decisions are made by consensus with the company, but these are just beliefs and assumptions, such as the idea that the change in management could also have been agreed upon with them, or the purchase of SMCC, etc. There will surely be decisions made by consensus for the good of the company, but I don't know to what extent they are decisive in the final decision-making. We shareholders can think or believe things freely, but that doesn't necessarily mean it will happen, have happened, or be true. And this is also an opinion, my personal one. I also don't believe they're responsible for everything the company might have done wrong, because management will have the final say, regardless of Cavendish's advice, which includes things like changing the name or the management, for example. In any case, I prefer to look to the future rather than the past, hence my concern that things are done right for the future good of the company, and that as few mistakes as possible are made. But that's not in my hands, as I'm just a shareholder who can only offer my opinion

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: My analysis wasn't based on Yahoo Finance, although there might be some similarities in the final conclusions, because Yahoo Finance uses AI to obtain those results. This AI researches multiple analysts simultaneously, which may include those I've researched. Regarding Cavendish, I see you have considerable confidence in them for whatever reason, and I have no objection. However, I understand the trades you mentioned they make, as it's normal, especially when a company has such low trading volume. But I'm referring to another type of trade, already discussed in this forum, with specific dates and times. These were instances of stock purchases, without any intervening sales, and instead of the price rising or falling due to supply and demand, it not only didn't rise, it didn't even stay the same, but the stock was sold below the trading price at that moment, inexplicably.

data.author: Sometimes
data.content: I also hope that Haydale succeeds, as I am also invested. With regard to your previous post about Cavendish and the Yahoo report, yes Cavendish worked with the previous management, but they also might in their duty to all shareholders have been involved in the management changes, whilst they are paid by Haydale I think they also have fidicuary responsibility to all shareholders. The Yahoo report is AI generated and will have combined all data it can find, but will always give the "Investment" warning for all Companies that have prior losses, which is inevitable in new technology companies and is after all why AIM evolved and has its tax breaks. Regarding trading in the market, my hypothesis on how the professionals operate is, imagine you are an ambitious fund manager whose usual investment value would be a multiple of the normal market daily trade value and let us go back a few weeks to when the share price was 0.6p with a spread of 0.55-0.65 and say the size is 1.5m shares bid with one market maker and offered with 2 also 1.5m each, the wise fund manager would instruct his dealer to bid 0.56 for 10m shares with a minimum start size of 3m. If at close of play the dealer or his market maker friend has accumulated 5m shares there will be a load of smaller trades under 0.56 and then the late reporting of the 5m at 0.56 and they will all show as sales or unknown! Also the two market makers who were offering at 0.65  if they had not been involved in the trades they would try and muscle in by lowering their offer prices, to attract the buyer to them. In this scenario buying looks like selling and the price has fallen!! Just my thoughts.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: I also hope Haydale succeeds, because I'm in this boat too, and although dreams are part of life, I personally prefer to keep my feet on the ground so that my dreams come true and don't remain just illusions. Everyone has their own opinion and way of doing things, and this is mine. And I don't know if the decisions are, or can be, agreed upon with Cavendish, which I assume they are, but in the recent past, fatal mistakes have been made for the development of the business, and although I'm aware of the change in the company's direction, starting with the top executives, the advisors in this case remain the same, which doesn't inspire much confidence. In the transactions handled by the market maker, I've often seen deals that, at the very least, can be described as strange, and I'm not the only person on this forum who has had a negative opinion about this.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Haydale Graphene's overall score is primarily influenced by its financial difficulties, with persistent net losses and cash flow problems overshadowing recent positive corporate events and technical momentum. While strategic developments and partnerships offer growth potential, financial stability remains a crucial concern. This is what professional market analysts think about the company's latest news. We shareholders can talk, criticize, exchange opinions, think, or believe whatever we want, but without results until February, the market, in its objective analysis, without bias, speculation, or speculation, has already formed its opinion of Haydale. And that could be a heavy burden if the results presented in February aren't satisfactory enough for the market. This is a risk that could have been avoided by presenting results in December. I hope I'm wrong and that in February I have to eat my words; that would be a huge success for all of us who want this company to succeed.

data.content: Haydale Graphene Industries PLC has successfully completed the acquisition of SaveMoneyCutCarbon (SMCC) and raised approximately £5.75 million in gross proceeds through a fundraising. This acquisition is considered a transformational step, creating a scalable, graphene-enabled clean-tech platform with immediate market access, integrating SMCC's customer acquisition engine and B2B delivery platform with Haydale's advanced materials and technologies like JustHeat. The enlarged group is now positioned to address the growing demand for decarbonisation solutions in the built environment, with integration of SMCC underway and SMCC's CEO joining the board as Chief Commercial Officer.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Doing things haphazardly breeds distrust. If they don't present results until after raising all the new capital, it conveys the feeling that everything announced so far hasn't yielded sufficiently strong or interesting financial results for shareholders to invest their money in the company. Then it makes sense that they did it the way they did. "First we raise the money, and then we give the results, just in case they disappoint the investors, we already have the money." I don't think it's honest. But that's just my personal opinion. I was happy with the company's progress and excited about the recent good news, but not with this move. And personally, I don't care if the shares skyrocket or rise gradually; that's not what my opinion is about. I'm talking about transparency, good faith, and honesty. Simply put.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: On the other hand, the overbuying of newly issued shares also seems strange to me, because there isn't a very advantageous offer at the initial offering price for existing shareholders, given that the price was practically at market value, with only a minimal advantage. Where is the offer for shareholders? You can buy them at that price today, so why don't you go to the market to buy the ones you couldn't buy at the discounted price? I have my doubts about the effectiveness of how things have been handled, in such a rushed manner. Time will tell

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: One thing doesn't negate the other. I mean, you can't start building a house from the roof down. The new company is currently losing money. But I'm not just referring to the new acquisition; Haydale has had financial problems from the beginning, a decade ago. Now it was starting to recover, after bleeding dry for a long time. First, get your house in order, and then you do whatever else is necessary. Present results, confirm the promised cost reductions, and confirm according to management. From there, we continue moving forward. There's no need to mortgage your resources again if there's no rush, because the company hasn't yet confirmed its good performance with strong financial results, aside from some good news, but without any clear results. The first thing to do is start there, consolidating the foundations, which you don't have.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: What I meant by the company's financial problem regarding analysts' opinions is that it exists, and it's real, whether it's from Yahoo Finance with AI, or from any reputable analyst, from whom the AI ​​draws its information. Until proven otherwise, and there's only one way to do that, which is by presenting the results without the delay that's going to happen in this case, to send positive signals that could help finance the company, whether through the market with options, a share offering, loans, or whatever they deem most appropriate and advantageous. On the other hand, I'm surprised that there has been so much oversubscription by shareholders without having real and properly updated data. It surprises me greatly. I see too much enthusiasm, which could cause them to lose sight of the real objective.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Furthermore, you believe that decisions are made by consensus with the company, but these are just beliefs and assumptions, such as the idea that the change in management could also have been agreed upon with them, or the purchase of SMCC, etc. There will surely be decisions made by consensus for the good of the company, but I don't know to what extent they are decisive in the final decision-making. We shareholders can think or believe things freely, but that doesn't necessarily mean it will happen, have happened, or be true. And this is also an opinion, my personal one. I also don't believe they're responsible for everything the company might have done wrong, because management will have the final say, regardless of Cavendish's advice, which includes things like changing the name or the management, for example. In any case, I prefer to look to the future rather than the past, hence my concern that things are done right for the future good of the company, and that as few mistakes as possible are made. But that's not in my hands, as I'm just a shareholder who can only offer my opinion

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: My analysis wasn't based on Yahoo Finance, although there might be some similarities in the final conclusions, because Yahoo Finance uses AI to obtain those results. This AI researches multiple analysts simultaneously, which may include those I've researched. Regarding Cavendish, I see you have considerable confidence in them for whatever reason, and I have no objection. However, I understand the trades you mentioned they make, as it's normal, especially when a company has such low trading volume. But I'm referring to another type of trade, already discussed in this forum, with specific dates and times. These were instances of stock purchases, without any intervening sales, and instead of the price rising or falling due to supply and demand, it not only didn't rise, it didn't even stay the same, but the stock was sold below the trading price at that moment, inexplicably.

data.author: Sometimes
data.content: I also hope that Haydale succeeds, as I am also invested. With regard to your previous post about Cavendish and the Yahoo report, yes Cavendish worked with the previous management, but they also might in their duty to all shareholders have been involved in the management changes, whilst they are paid by Haydale I think they also have fidicuary responsibility to all shareholders. The Yahoo report is AI generated and will have combined all data it can find, but will always give the "Investment" warning for all Companies that have prior losses, which is inevitable in new technology companies and is after all why AIM evolved and has its tax breaks. Regarding trading in the market, my hypothesis on how the professionals operate is, imagine you are an ambitious fund manager whose usual investment value would be a multiple of the normal market daily trade value and let us go back a few weeks to when the share price was 0.6p with a spread of 0.55-0.65 and say the size is 1.5m shares bid with one market maker and offered with 2 also 1.5m each, the wise fund manager would instruct his dealer to bid 0.56 for 10m shares with a minimum start size of 3m. If at close of play the dealer or his market maker friend has accumulated 5m shares there will be a load of smaller trades under 0.56 and then the late reporting of the 5m at 0.56 and they will all show as sales or unknown! Also the two market makers who were offering at 0.65  if they had not been involved in the trades they would try and muscle in by lowering their offer prices, to attract the buyer to them. In this scenario buying looks like selling and the price has fallen!! Just my thoughts.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: I also hope Haydale succeeds, because I'm in this boat too, and although dreams are part of life, I personally prefer to keep my feet on the ground so that my dreams come true and don't remain just illusions. Everyone has their own opinion and way of doing things, and this is mine. And I don't know if the decisions are, or can be, agreed upon with Cavendish, which I assume they are, but in the recent past, fatal mistakes have been made for the development of the business, and although I'm aware of the change in the company's direction, starting with the top executives, the advisors in this case remain the same, which doesn't inspire much confidence. In the transactions handled by the market maker, I've often seen deals that, at the very least, can be described as strange, and I'm not the only person on this forum who has had a negative opinion about this.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Haydale Graphene's overall score is primarily influenced by its financial difficulties, with persistent net losses and cash flow problems overshadowing recent positive corporate events and technical momentum. While strategic developments and partnerships offer growth potential, financial stability remains a crucial concern. This is what professional market analysts think about the company's latest news. We shareholders can talk, criticize, exchange opinions, think, or believe whatever we want, but without results until February, the market, in its objective analysis, without bias, speculation, or speculation, has already formed its opinion of Haydale. And that could be a heavy burden if the results presented in February aren't satisfactory enough for the market. This is a risk that could have been avoided by presenting results in December. I hope I'm wrong and that in February I have to eat my words; that would be a huge success for all of us who want this company to succeed.

data.content: Haydale Graphene Industries PLC has successfully completed the acquisition of SaveMoneyCutCarbon (SMCC) and raised approximately £5.75 million in gross proceeds through a fundraising. This acquisition is considered a transformational step, creating a scalable, graphene-enabled clean-tech platform with immediate market access, integrating SMCC's customer acquisition engine and B2B delivery platform with Haydale's advanced materials and technologies like JustHeat. The enlarged group is now positioned to address the growing demand for decarbonisation solutions in the built environment, with integration of SMCC underway and SMCC's CEO joining the board as Chief Commercial Officer.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Merciaman, I completely understand what you're saying, and I agree. But I think it would have been necessary to know the company's current state a year after the last general meeting, where the difficult situation the company was going through was clearly explained. Well, if things have improved now, even if not dramatically, but the measures they decided to take a year ago have managed to improve things, even if only slightly, it would be fair to say so, just as they bluntly stated last year that things were going badly and outlined the adjustments they had to make. That's fine, we need to be clear and realistic and know where we stand. Because it seems that shareholders went into the offer to acquire new shares with enthusiasm, but without real information, and the same mistakes of the past are being repeated, which is why many shareholders are disappointed with the company's performance, especially those who have been invested longer and made disastrous investments.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Doing things haphazardly breeds distrust. If they don't present results until after raising all the new capital, it conveys the feeling that everything announced so far hasn't yielded sufficiently strong or interesting financial results for shareholders to invest their money in the company. Then it makes sense that they did it the way they did. "First we raise the money, and then we give the results, just in case they disappoint the investors, we already have the money." I don't think it's honest. But that's just my personal opinion. I was happy with the company's progress and excited about the recent good news, but not with this move. And personally, I don't care if the shares skyrocket or rise gradually; that's not what my opinion is about. I'm talking about transparency, good faith, and honesty. Simply put.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: On the other hand, the overbuying of newly issued shares also seems strange to me, because there isn't a very advantageous offer at the initial offering price for existing shareholders, given that the price was practically at market value, with only a minimal advantage. Where is the offer for shareholders? You can buy them at that price today, so why don't you go to the market to buy the ones you couldn't buy at the discounted price? I have my doubts about the effectiveness of how things have been handled, in such a rushed manner. Time will tell

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: One thing doesn't negate the other. I mean, you can't start building a house from the roof down. The new company is currently losing money. But I'm not just referring to the new acquisition; Haydale has had financial problems from the beginning, a decade ago. Now it was starting to recover, after bleeding dry for a long time. First, get your house in order, and then you do whatever else is necessary. Present results, confirm the promised cost reductions, and confirm according to management. From there, we continue moving forward. There's no need to mortgage your resources again if there's no rush, because the company hasn't yet confirmed its good performance with strong financial results, aside from some good news, but without any clear results. The first thing to do is start there, consolidating the foundations, which you don't have.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Thoughtful comments, particularly from Roberson and Albatross. From what I can see, the business has changed very significantly over the past 12 to 15 months - now focussing on commercialising its existing graphene applications, and focussing more on the UK. In so doing it has sharply reduced its cost base and, arguably, improved its chances of success in a (graphene) sector that has seen, let's be honest, much failure and little success. The company we now have doesn't seem to have the structure that could drive incremental growth in fragmented sectors (like housing), and hence the acquisition of SMCC seems sensible - to provide such a structure. The price tag still seems high, but fingers crossed it will succeed. From a shareholding perspective I think this makes Haydale a less speculative punt (though still speculative to a degree) with a greater chance of incremental (but less spectacular) success. I imagine that will please some shareholders and not others. And of course they can still develop other commercial applications that might be more spectacularly successful. Let's hope so.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: What I meant by the company's financial problem regarding analysts' opinions is that it exists, and it's real, whether it's from Yahoo Finance with AI, or from any reputable analyst, from whom the AI ​​draws its information. Until proven otherwise, and there's only one way to do that, which is by presenting the results without the delay that's going to happen in this case, to send positive signals that could help finance the company, whether through the market with options, a share offering, loans, or whatever they deem most appropriate and advantageous. On the other hand, I'm surprised that there has been so much oversubscription by shareholders without having real and properly updated data. It surprises me greatly. I see too much enthusiasm, which could cause them to lose sight of the real objective.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Furthermore, you believe that decisions are made by consensus with the company, but these are just beliefs and assumptions, such as the idea that the change in management could also have been agreed upon with them, or the purchase of SMCC, etc. There will surely be decisions made by consensus for the good of the company, but I don't know to what extent they are decisive in the final decision-making. We shareholders can think or believe things freely, but that doesn't necessarily mean it will happen, have happened, or be true. And this is also an opinion, my personal one. I also don't believe they're responsible for everything the company might have done wrong, because management will have the final say, regardless of Cavendish's advice, which includes things like changing the name or the management, for example. In any case, I prefer to look to the future rather than the past, hence my concern that things are done right for the future good of the company, and that as few mistakes as possible are made. But that's not in my hands, as I'm just a shareholder who can only offer my opinion

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: My analysis wasn't based on Yahoo Finance, although there might be some similarities in the final conclusions, because Yahoo Finance uses AI to obtain those results. This AI researches multiple analysts simultaneously, which may include those I've researched. Regarding Cavendish, I see you have considerable confidence in them for whatever reason, and I have no objection. However, I understand the trades you mentioned they make, as it's normal, especially when a company has such low trading volume. But I'm referring to another type of trade, already discussed in this forum, with specific dates and times. These were instances of stock purchases, without any intervening sales, and instead of the price rising or falling due to supply and demand, it not only didn't rise, it didn't even stay the same, but the stock was sold below the trading price at that moment, inexplicably.

data.author: Sometimes
data.content: I also hope that Haydale succeeds, as I am also invested. With regard to your previous post about Cavendish and the Yahoo report, yes Cavendish worked with the previous management, but they also might in their duty to all shareholders have been involved in the management changes, whilst they are paid by Haydale I think they also have fidicuary responsibility to all shareholders. The Yahoo report is AI generated and will have combined all data it can find, but will always give the "Investment" warning for all Companies that have prior losses, which is inevitable in new technology companies and is after all why AIM evolved and has its tax breaks. Regarding trading in the market, my hypothesis on how the professionals operate is, imagine you are an ambitious fund manager whose usual investment value would be a multiple of the normal market daily trade value and let us go back a few weeks to when the share price was 0.6p with a spread of 0.55-0.65 and say the size is 1.5m shares bid with one market maker and offered with 2 also 1.5m each, the wise fund manager would instruct his dealer to bid 0.56 for 10m shares with a minimum start size of 3m. If at close of play the dealer or his market maker friend has accumulated 5m shares there will be a load of smaller trades under 0.56 and then the late reporting of the 5m at 0.56 and they will all show as sales or unknown! Also the two market makers who were offering at 0.65  if they had not been involved in the trades they would try and muscle in by lowering their offer prices, to attract the buyer to them. In this scenario buying looks like selling and the price has fallen!! Just my thoughts.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: I also hope Haydale succeeds, because I'm in this boat too, and although dreams are part of life, I personally prefer to keep my feet on the ground so that my dreams come true and don't remain just illusions. Everyone has their own opinion and way of doing things, and this is mine. And I don't know if the decisions are, or can be, agreed upon with Cavendish, which I assume they are, but in the recent past, fatal mistakes have been made for the development of the business, and although I'm aware of the change in the company's direction, starting with the top executives, the advisors in this case remain the same, which doesn't inspire much confidence. In the transactions handled by the market maker, I've often seen deals that, at the very least, can be described as strange, and I'm not the only person on this forum who has had a negative opinion about this.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Haydale Graphene's overall score is primarily influenced by its financial difficulties, with persistent net losses and cash flow problems overshadowing recent positive corporate events and technical momentum. While strategic developments and partnerships offer growth potential, financial stability remains a crucial concern. This is what professional market analysts think about the company's latest news. We shareholders can talk, criticize, exchange opinions, think, or believe whatever we want, but without results until February, the market, in its objective analysis, without bias, speculation, or speculation, has already formed its opinion of Haydale. And that could be a heavy burden if the results presented in February aren't satisfactory enough for the market. This is a risk that could have been avoided by presenting results in December. I hope I'm wrong and that in February I have to eat my words; that would be a huge success for all of us who want this company to succeed.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Doing things haphazardly breeds distrust. If they don't present results until after raising all the new capital, it conveys the feeling that everything announced so far hasn't yielded sufficiently strong or interesting financial results for shareholders to invest their money in the company. Then it makes sense that they did it the way they did. "First we raise the money, and then we give the results, just in case they disappoint the investors, we already have the money." I don't think it's honest. But that's just my personal opinion. I was happy with the company's progress and excited about the recent good news, but not with this move. And personally, I don't care if the shares skyrocket or rise gradually; that's not what my opinion is about. I'm talking about transparency, good faith, and honesty. Simply put.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: On the other hand, the overbuying of newly issued shares also seems strange to me, because there isn't a very advantageous offer at the initial offering price for existing shareholders, given that the price was practically at market value, with only a minimal advantage. Where is the offer for shareholders? You can buy them at that price today, so why don't you go to the market to buy the ones you couldn't buy at the discounted price? I have my doubts about the effectiveness of how things have been handled, in such a rushed manner. Time will tell

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: One thing doesn't negate the other. I mean, you can't start building a house from the roof down. The new company is currently losing money. But I'm not just referring to the new acquisition; Haydale has had financial problems from the beginning, a decade ago. Now it was starting to recover, after bleeding dry for a long time. First, get your house in order, and then you do whatever else is necessary. Present results, confirm the promised cost reductions, and confirm according to management. From there, we continue moving forward. There's no need to mortgage your resources again if there's no rush, because the company hasn't yet confirmed its good performance with strong financial results, aside from some good news, but without any clear results. The first thing to do is start there, consolidating the foundations, which you don't have.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Thoughtful comments, particularly from Roberson and Albatross. From what I can see, the business has changed very significantly over the past 12 to 15 months - now focussing on commercialising its existing graphene applications, and focussing more on the UK. In so doing it has sharply reduced its cost base and, arguably, improved its chances of success in a (graphene) sector that has seen, let's be honest, much failure and little success. The company we now have doesn't seem to have the structure that could drive incremental growth in fragmented sectors (like housing), and hence the acquisition of SMCC seems sensible - to provide such a structure. The price tag still seems high, but fingers crossed it will succeed. From a shareholding perspective I think this makes Haydale a less speculative punt (though still speculative to a degree) with a greater chance of incremental (but less spectacular) success. I imagine that will please some shareholders and not others. And of course they can still develop other commercial applications that might be more spectacularly successful. Let's hope so.

At a time that seemed opportune to strengthen the company's value by improving the current share price and thereby appease the long-suffering shareholders by presenting positive financial results and driving up the share price, are they embarking on the risky project of asking for yet another sacrifice from the already hard-suffering shareholders? They say this move is to compensate the long-suffering shareholders. I don't agree, with all due respect to the board's decisions.

data.title: Notice of Annual Results
data.full_content:
Today 07:00
RNS Number : 4758S
Haydale PLC
11 February 2026
Haydale Plc
("Haydale", the "Company" or the "Group")
Notice of Annual Results
Haydale (AIM: HAYD), the global advanced materials and clean-tech company focused on deploying energy and water-efficient technologies at scale will announce its audited results for the 15 months ended 30 September 2025 on Tuesday, 17 February 2026. The Board looks forward to updating shareholders with further details at that time.
For further information:
Haydale Plc
Simon Turek, Chief Executive Officer Tel: +44 (0) 1269 842946
Gareth Kaminski-Cook, Non-Executive Chair
Patrick Carter, Chief Financial Officer
www.haydale.com
Cavendish Capital Markets Limited (Nominated Adviser & Broker)
Julian Blunt / Edward Whiley / Trisyia Jamaludin, Corporate Finance Tel: +44 (0) 20 7220 0500
Andrew Burdis, ECM
About Haydale
Haydale plc is an advanced materials and clean-technology company focused on the development and deployment of energy- and water-efficient technologies at scale.
The Group leverages its proprietary HDPlas® platform technology to develop patented graphene-enabled products across heating, cooling and energy-efficiency applications. These technologies are deployed through an integrated commercial model that combines in-house product development with established customer access, delivery capability and long-term partner relationships, including through the SaveMoneyCutCarbon Impact Partner programme.
Haydale's strategy is focused on accelerating the deployment of cost-effective decarbonisation solutions across the UK's built environment, while building a scalable platform for wider international deployment through strategic partners. The Group is execution-led and product-focused, translating advanced materials science into commercially deployable solutions that deliver measurable energy, water and carbon savings.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: What I meant by the company's financial problem regarding analysts' opinions is that it exists, and it's real, whether it's from Yahoo Finance with AI, or from any reputable analyst, from whom the AI ​​draws its information. Until proven otherwise, and there's only one way to do that, which is by presenting the results without the delay that's going to happen in this case, to send positive signals that could help finance the company, whether through the market with options, a share offering, loans, or whatever they deem most appropriate and advantageous. On the other hand, I'm surprised that there has been so much oversubscription by shareholders without having real and properly updated data. It surprises me greatly. I see too much enthusiasm, which could cause them to lose sight of the real objective.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Furthermore, you believe that decisions are made by consensus with the company, but these are just beliefs and assumptions, such as the idea that the change in management could also have been agreed upon with them, or the purchase of SMCC, etc. There will surely be decisions made by consensus for the good of the company, but I don't know to what extent they are decisive in the final decision-making. We shareholders can think or believe things freely, but that doesn't necessarily mean it will happen, have happened, or be true. And this is also an opinion, my personal one. I also don't believe they're responsible for everything the company might have done wrong, because management will have the final say, regardless of Cavendish's advice, which includes things like changing the name or the management, for example. In any case, I prefer to look to the future rather than the past, hence my concern that things are done right for the future good of the company, and that as few mistakes as possible are made. But that's not in my hands, as I'm just a shareholder who can only offer my opinion

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: My analysis wasn't based on Yahoo Finance, although there might be some similarities in the final conclusions, because Yahoo Finance uses AI to obtain those results. This AI researches multiple analysts simultaneously, which may include those I've researched. Regarding Cavendish, I see you have considerable confidence in them for whatever reason, and I have no objection. However, I understand the trades you mentioned they make, as it's normal, especially when a company has such low trading volume. But I'm referring to another type of trade, already discussed in this forum, with specific dates and times. These were instances of stock purchases, without any intervening sales, and instead of the price rising or falling due to supply and demand, it not only didn't rise, it didn't even stay the same, but the stock was sold below the trading price at that moment, inexplicably.

data.author: Deepsurvey1
data.content: HAYD x 2 bagger to start with. The Race is on to mass produce a plenty full supply of Graphene for electronics, batteries and solar panels  to take over from silver - because there isn’t enough silver anywhere.

data.author: Sometimes
data.content: I also hope that Haydale succeeds, as I am also invested. With regard to your previous post about Cavendish and the Yahoo report, yes Cavendish worked with the previous management, but they also might in their duty to all shareholders have been involved in the management changes, whilst they are paid by Haydale I think they also have fidicuary responsibility to all shareholders. The Yahoo report is AI generated and will have combined all data it can find, but will always give the "Investment" warning for all Companies that have prior losses, which is inevitable in new technology companies and is after all why AIM evolved and has its tax breaks. Regarding trading in the market, my hypothesis on how the professionals operate is, imagine you are an ambitious fund manager whose usual investment value would be a multiple of the normal market daily trade value and let us go back a few weeks to when the share price was 0.6p with a spread of 0.55-0.65 and say the size is 1.5m shares bid with one market maker and offered with 2 also 1.5m each, the wise fund manager would instruct his dealer to bid 0.56 for 10m shares with a minimum start size of 3m. If at close of play the dealer or his market maker friend has accumulated 5m shares there will be a load of smaller trades under 0.56 and then the late reporting of the 5m at 0.56 and they will all show as sales or unknown! Also the two market makers who were offering at 0.65  if they had not been involved in the trades they would try and muscle in by lowering their offer prices, to attract the buyer to them. In this scenario buying looks like selling and the price has fallen!! Just my thoughts.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: I also hope Haydale succeeds, because I'm in this boat too, and although dreams are part of life, I personally prefer to keep my feet on the ground so that my dreams come true and don't remain just illusions. Everyone has their own opinion and way of doing things, and this is mine. And I don't know if the decisions are, or can be, agreed upon with Cavendish, which I assume they are, but in the recent past, fatal mistakes have been made for the development of the business, and although I'm aware of the change in the company's direction, starting with the top executives, the advisors in this case remain the same, which doesn't inspire much confidence. In the transactions handled by the market maker, I've often seen deals that, at the very least, can be described as strange, and I'm not the only person on this forum who has had a negative opinion about this.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Haydale Graphene's overall score is primarily influenced by its financial difficulties, with persistent net losses and cash flow problems overshadowing recent positive corporate events and technical momentum. While strategic developments and partnerships offer growth potential, financial stability remains a crucial concern. This is what professional market analysts think about the company's latest news. We shareholders can talk, criticize, exchange opinions, think, or believe whatever we want, but without results until February, the market, in its objective analysis, without bias, speculation, or speculation, has already formed its opinion of Haydale. And that could be a heavy burden if the results presented in February aren't satisfactory enough for the market. This is a risk that could have been avoided by presenting results in December. I hope I'm wrong and that in February I have to eat my words; that would be a huge success for all of us who want this company to succeed.

data.author: johndean
data.content: Haydale Graphene Industries PLC has successfully completed the acquisition of SaveMoneyCutCarbon (SMCC) and raised approximately £5.75 million in gross proceeds through a fundraising. This acquisition is considered a transformational step, creating a scalable, graphene-enabled clean-tech platform with immediate market access, integrating SMCC's customer acquisition engine and B2B delivery platform with Haydale's advanced materials and technologies like JustHeat. The enlarged group is now positioned to address the growing demand for decarbonisation solutions in the built environment, with integration of SMCC underway and SMCC's CEO joining the board as Chief Commercial Officer.

I’m holding til I’m bought out.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: I simply ask for clarity from the company, and that there be no false expectations that we might later regret. Shareholders are free to do what they want with their money, but they should be aware of the risks involved, based on real data, which, by the way, I believe is optimistic and considerably better than in previous years, even if it's not spectacular... but that's not necessary. It's good to improve little by little, but with a solid foundation.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Merciaman, I completely understand what you're saying, and I agree. But I think it would have been necessary to know the company's current state a year after the last general meeting, where the difficult situation the company was going through was clearly explained. Well, if things have improved now, even if not dramatically, but the measures they decided to take a year ago have managed to improve things, even if only slightly, it would be fair to say so, just as they bluntly stated last year that things were going badly and outlined the adjustments they had to make. That's fine, we need to be clear and realistic and know where we stand. Because it seems that shareholders went into the offer to acquire new shares with enthusiasm, but without real information, and the same mistakes of the past are being repeated, which is why many shareholders are disappointed with the company's performance, especially those who have been invested longer and made disastrous investments.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Roberson, I think they did indeed "trail" the FY results as being unspectacular when touching on them in the 12th December RNS -

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: Doing things haphazardly breeds distrust. If they don't present results until after raising all the new capital, it conveys the feeling that everything announced so far hasn't yielded sufficiently strong or interesting financial results for shareholders to invest their money in the company. Then it makes sense that they did it the way they did. "First we raise the money, and then we give the results, just in case they disappoint the investors, we already have the money." I don't think it's honest. But that's just my personal opinion. I was happy with the company's progress and excited about the recent good news, but not with this move. And personally, I don't care if the shares skyrocket or rise gradually; that's not what my opinion is about. I'm talking about transparency, good faith, and honesty. Simply put.

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: On the other hand, the overbuying of newly issued shares also seems strange to me, because there isn't a very advantageous offer at the initial offering price for existing shareholders, given that the price was practically at market value, with only a minimal advantage. Where is the offer for shareholders? You can buy them at that price today, so why don't you go to the market to buy the ones you couldn't buy at the discounted price? I have my doubts about the effectiveness of how things have been handled, in such a rushed manner. Time will tell

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: One thing doesn't negate the other. I mean, you can't start building a house from the roof down. The new company is currently losing money. But I'm not just referring to the new acquisition; Haydale has had financial problems from the beginning, a decade ago. Now it was starting to recover, after bleeding dry for a long time. First, get your house in order, and then you do whatever else is necessary. Present results, confirm the promised cost reductions, and confirm according to management. From there, we continue moving forward. There's no need to mortgage your resources again if there's no rush, because the company hasn't yet confirmed its good performance with strong financial results, aside from some good news, but without any clear results. The first thing to do is start there, consolidating the foundations, which you don't have.

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Thoughtful comments, particularly from Roberson and Albatross. From what I can see, the business has changed very significantly over the past 12 to 15 months - now focussing on commercialising its existing graphene applications, and focussing more on the UK. In so doing it has sharply reduced its cost base and, arguably, improved its chances of success in a (graphene) sector that has seen, let's be honest, much failure and little success. The company we now have doesn't seem to have the structure that could drive incremental growth in fragmented sectors (like housing), and hence the acquisition of SMCC seems sensible - to provide such a structure. The price tag still seems high, but fingers crossed it will succeed. From a shareholding perspective I think this makes Haydale a less speculative punt (though still speculative to a degree) with a greater chance of incremental (but less spectacular) success. I imagine that will please some shareholders and not others. And of course they can still develop other commercial applications that might be more spectacularly successful. Let's hope so.

data.author: Albatross747
data.content: Think there’s a lot going on behind the curtain, it may seem like they should have hunkered down and used just heat to make some money and let the share price improve but their duty is to the long term success of the company not just to short term making the shareholders happy. Without an integrated distribution method sales of Justheat could well have been looking to underperform. In theory this acquisition will help us hit the ground running. The fact that its loss making isn’t too relevant as it had been aggressively growing to establish itself in the sector which in theory we can now capitalise on. Becoming profitable may still be some time off but growing revenues will bolster the share price in the medium term. Big dilution sure but if the alternative was a bit of a drift higher followed by weak sales our best case would end up being an unfavourable sale.

data.author: Jennimee
data.content: Agreed. It does seem a strange move to make but surely they have done their own due diligence and have a structured plan to move the business forward? The commercial platform seems to be raising heads especially now we know the share offer was over subscribed. I think the company have viable product which potentially could be a market leader will we would hope would bring a market leading share price too. Big plans looking to materialise in the coming year? I think so! Good luck all

data.author: ROBERSON
data.content: The dilution of the current share price through a new capital increase of over three billion new shares to buy a loss-making company—after having to auction off and enter bankruptcy proceedings this year (2025) for its US branch, and selling off its Thai branch at a loss due to financial problems—doesn't seem very reasonable to me. At a time that seemed opportune to strengthen the company's value by improving the current share price and thereby appease the long-suffering shareholders by presenting positive financial results and driving up the share price, are they embarking on the risky project of asking for yet another sacrifice from the already hard-suffering shareholders? They say this move is to compensate the long-suffering shareholders. I don't agree, with all due respect to the board's decisions.

data.author: Albatross747
data.content: Wouldn’t be surprising if it dipped a bit more till next news but equally since oversubscribed there will be some support at 0.5. I took up the retail offer and only got 85% or whatever the number was so will buy the remainder on market as I can’t stand not having a nice round number of shares… can’t be the only one. Right?!

data.author: Merciaman
data.content: Crystal ball time I guess, but with a lot of shares due to hit the market at a price of 0.5p in the near future, I doubt the share price will move too much in the coming weeks - unless we have some surprising / positive news. There'll be activity in w/c 5th Jan with the the EGM on the 6th and the admission of consideration shares that week. Then there is the final results announcement scheduled for "early February". Suggest things will be clearer then.
